intro: Eremogone polycnemifolia, commonly known as the sandhill morning glory, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It is characterized by its delicate, trumpet-shaped flowers that open in the morning and close by midday. The plant has a sprawling growth habit with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. Its flowers are typically pale blue to purple in color, with five petals and a distinctive, recurved throat. Eremogone polycnemifolia is adapted to thrive in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in disturbed or open habitats.
